abstracts.cdata!:
The project's outcome is rated as
            satisfactory. The sustainability of the reform process is
            likely for two reasons: 1) The new law and regulatory
            authority provide a legal basis for the continuance of the
            reform. 2) The President has taken a personal interest in
            the sector and has requested IFC financing for the
            Information and Communications Technologies sector. Overall
            world Bank performance is assessed as satisfactory because
            Bank staff maintained a close dialogue with the government,
            provided techical assistance on key issues, and factored in
            global changes in the ICT sector into the progress of the
            project. Borrower performance is rated satisfactory overall.
            Some of the lessons learned include: First, training and
            capacity building are a necessary component in projects
            seeking to introduce technological and institutional
            innovation. Second, projects with long durations need to
            take into account significant changes in the sector, and
            adjust project objectives to respond to these changes.
            Third, it is important to leverage potential synergies
            between multiple operations in any country in order to
            achieve sector and development objectives. Fourth, the
            failure of privatization and the erosion of investor
            confidence caused by the dispute with the privatization
            advisor demonstrated that it is crucial for the government
            to establish appropriate contractual arrangements. Fifth,
            sound project design and implementation helped the reform
            process withstand major setbacks.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Telecommunications Project consists
            of three components. The first component,
            rehabilitation/expansion of the Telecommunications Network,
            includes the implementation of a digital overlay network in
            high priority demand areas for business subscribers and
            other economic agents. This component will improve
            international access and service quality for the overall
            network. The second component, institutional development,
            includes assistance to the telecommunications operator
            (Kyrgyz Telecom) to carry out institutional reforms. The
            third component, sector restructuring, provides assistance
            to the Ministry of Communications to carry out the reform
            program and to train Ministry staff in regulation and policy formulation.
